pysqlc.DB — reference and examples¶

This page contains an overview of nlpru and all availible methods

Initiation¶

class DB([env_name="dev"][, _debug_mode=False][, database][, dbtype][, username][, password][, host][, charset])¶

The DB oject creates a connection to the SQL server database, verifies db connection based on db name specified, and executes prepared statements.

Acts as a single interface for I/O to the DB server

Parameters

  • env_name – environment you wish to connect to, only applicable if you are using the environmental variable approach

  • database – name of the database you want to connect to

  • username – manually input username if not utilizing environmental variable approach

  • password – manually input the passwords if not utilizing environmental variable approach

  • host – specify the server host if not utilizing environmental variable approach, for example “localhost”

  • charset – character set if not utilizing environmental variable approach, for example “utf8mb4”

  • _debug_mode – specify whether you want pysqlc to provide transparency on all operations (print to console)

Pram dbtype

specify the RDMS server type you use: “MySQL” allowed

Query¶

DB.query([sql_query][, values=None][, q_type="SELECT"][, executemany=False])¶

The main operating method for all CRUD operations. Expects a SQL query as a string, and allows customizations with 3 parameters.

Parameters

  • sql_query – mandatory, actual SQL query as a string

  • values – if q_type=”INSERT”, the values to go along with the string SQL query.

  • q_type – the type of CRUD operation being utilized, ‘INSERT’, ‘REPLACE’, ‘DELETE’, and ‘UPDATE’, and ‘CREATE’ are allowed.

  • executemany – specify if you want to do a batch operation

Return type

list of tuples for q_type=”SELECT”, None for all others

Examples¶

SELECT query, a result is returned

  • q_type = “SELECT” (default)

  • values optional

q = "SELECT * FROM table;"
result = db.query(q)
INSERT query (nothing returned)

  • q_type = ‘INSERT’

  • values - the values that will be committed

Insert one row

query = "INSERT IGNORE INTO table (userid, username) VALUES (%s, %s);"
values = [123,'john smith']
db.query(query, values, q_type='INSERT')

Insert multiple rows

query = "INSERT IGNORE INTO table (userid, username) VALUES (%s, %s);"
values = [(123,'john smith'),(456,'elon musk'),(789,'bill gates')]
db.query(query, values, q_type='INSERT', executemany=True)
UPDATE query (as above)

  • need q_type = ‘DELETE’

  • values = None (or skip)

query = "UPDATE table SET username = %s WHERE userid = %s;"
values = ['john smith', 123]
db.query(query, values, q_type='UPDATE')
REPLACE query (nothing returned)

  • q_type = ‘REPLACE’

  • values - the values that will be committed

CREATE query (nothing returned)

  • need q_type = ‘CREATE’

  • values = None (or skip)

query = """
CREATE TABLE IF NOT EXISTS users (
    userid INT AUTO_INCREMENT PRIMARY KEY,
    username VARCHAR(15)
)
db.query(query, q_type="CREATE")
"""
DELETE query (again, nothing returned)

  • need q_type = ‘DELETE’

  • values = None (or skip)

query = "DELETE FROM table WHERE id = %s;"
values = [123]
db.query(query, values, q_type="DELETE")
